Literature Review: Psychoneuroimmunology (PNI) is an interdisciplinary field that explores the interactions between the immune system, the nervous system, and psychological processes. Over the past few decades, research in PNI has significantly advanced our understanding of how immune-to-brain communication influences neural and psychological development and function across the lifespan. This review aims to introduce the basic physiology of immune-to-brain signaling, focusing on inflammation, and to highlight its implications for clinical psychology.The neuroimmune network is a complex system that facilitates bidirectional communication between the immune system and the brain. Immune cells, such as macrophages and microglia, release cytokines and other signaling molecules that can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) or interact with peripheral nerves to influence brain function (Dantzer, O'Connor, Freund, Johnson, & Kelley, 2008). Cytokines, including interleukin-1 (IL-1), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), are key mediators of this communication. These cytokines can activate the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, leading to the release of stress hormones such as cortisol, which in turn can modulate immune responses (McEwen, 2007).Immune activation can have profound effects on psychological domains, including positive and negative valence systems, social processes, cognition, and arousal. For instance, inflammation has been linked to the development of depressive symptoms, a phenomenon known as 'sickness behavior' (Dantzer et al., 2008). Sickness behavior is characterized by fatigue, anhedonia, social withdrawal, and cognitive impairment, all of which are common symptoms of depression. Preclinical studies have shown that systemic inflammation can induce depressive-like behaviors in rodents, and these behaviors can be reversed by anti-inflammatory treatments (Miller, Maletic, & Raison, 2009).In humans, chronic low-grade inflammation has been associated with an increased risk of major depressive disorder (MDD) (Kiecolt-Glaser, Derry, & Fagundes, 2015). Elevated levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-6 and TNF-α, have been observed in patients with MDD, and these levels correlate with the severity of depressive symptoms (Miller et al., 2009). Furthermore, anti-inflammatory agents, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and cytokine inhibitors, have shown promise in reducing depressive symptoms in clinical trials (Kiecolt-Glaser et al., 2015).In addition to depression, immune activation has been implicated in the pathophysiology of other psychological disorders, including posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety, and schizophrenia. For example, individuals with PTSD have been found to have higher levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and a dysregulated HPA axis, which may contribute to the chronic stress and hyperarousal characteristic of the disorder (O'Donovan, Ahmadi, & Yehuda, 2017). Similarly, anxiety disorders have been associated with increased inflammation, and anti-inflammatory treatments have been shown to reduce anxiety symptoms in preclinical models (O'Donovan et al., 2017).Schizophrenia, a complex psychiatric disorder characterized by cognitive and social impairments, has also been linked to immune dysregulation. Postmortem studies have revealed increased levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in the brains of individuals with schizophrenia, and genetic studies have identified immune-related genes as risk factors for the disorder (Miller et al., 2009). These findings suggest that immune activation may contribute to the neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative processes underlying schizophrenia.Psychosocial stress is a critical modulator of neuroimmune activity and can exacerbate the effects of immune activation on psychological function. Chronic stress has been shown to increase the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and to impair the function of regulatory T cells, which are important for maintaining immune homeostasis (Segerstrom & Miller, 2004). Early life adversity, such as childhood maltreatment, can have long-lasting effects on the neuroimmune system, leading to increased vulnerability to psychological disorders later in life (Heim & Nemeroff, 2001).Early life stress can alter the development of the HPA axis and the immune system, leading to a state of chronic low-grade inflammation that persists into adulthood (Heim & Nemeroff, 2001). This chronic inflammation can contribute to the development of mood and anxiety disorders, as well as cognitive impairments. For example, individuals with a history of childhood maltreatment have been found to have higher levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and a greater risk of developing depression and anxiety disorders (Heim & Nemeroff, 2001).Given the bidirectional nature of the neuroimmune network, psychosocial and mind-body interventions that influence the immune system may promote neuroimmune resilience and improve psychological outcomes. Mindfulness-based interventions, such as mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), have been shown to reduce inflammation and improve mood and cognitive function in individuals with chronic stress and psychological disorders (Creswell, Lindsay, & Brown, 2012). Similarly, physical exercise has been found to have anti-inflammatory effects and to improve symptoms of depression and anxiety (Sweat & Babyak, 2015).In conclusion, the field of psychoneuroimmunology has provided valuable insights into the complex interactions between the immune system, the nervous system, and psychological processes. Immune-to-brain communication, particularly through inflammation, plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of psychological disorders. Understanding these interactions has important implications for the development of novel therapeutic interventions that target the neuroimmune system to improve psychological health.
